title: 108_s2790
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" and involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the issuance of bidding rights certificates to holders of withdrawn coal preference right lease applications by the Secretary of the Interior. Relinquishment of all associated rights is required for withdrawn applications. The relinquishment of all rights for withdrawn coal preference lease applications is effective upon the issuance of the bidding rights certificate under section 4(a)(2), without further adjudication by the Secretary. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. The fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications is determined by a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The panel determining the fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications consists of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the holder of the preference right lease application, and the Governor of New Mexico. The Secretary will contract with a qualified coal reserve appraiser to assist the panel in determining the value. The panel may supplement information as needed. The panel, consisting of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the lease holder, and the Governor of New Mexico, will determine the fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications. A qualified coal reserve appraiser will assist the panel in this determination. The panel may supplement information as necessary and must submit their determination to the Secretary within 75 days. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application. This is to satisfy the Navajo Nation's land selection rights and promote land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. Additionally, a certificate of bidding rights must be issued based on fair market value. The Secretary must issue a certificate of bidding rights based on fair market value, which is enforceable in a mandamus proceeding. SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) allows for transferability and can be used as a credit against payments for Federal coal leases. Production royalties and bonus payments are payable to the Secretary under Federal coal leases. In cases where a certificate of bidding rights is used as a credit against a payment obligation, the holder can apply the bidding rights to 50% of the amount payable under the lease, with the remaining 50% to be paid as specified. Any payment of a Federal coal lease obligation by the holder of a certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) shall be split into 50% paid in cash or equivalent, with the remaining 50% distributed to the State where the lease is located. The payment of a Federal coal lease obligation by the holder of a certificate of bidding rights is split into 50% cash payment and 50% distributed to the State where the lease is located. Additionally, 50% of the amount paid through a crediting of the bidding rights is subject to redistribution under the Mineral Leasing Act.
